commentBody:
We The People will always, all ways, be the targets of our own greed and evil, because our vast wealth and privilege is not enough: 

Our corporate betters must forever dream up new horrors to inflict on us, new misery, dismemberment and death by any means necessary. Rather than invest in our health and welfare, and those of other humans on earth, we only seek death

In the Wikipedia article on the Convention on Cluster Muntions (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convention_on_Cluster_Munitions#State_parties) the USA and Russia are absent from the signatories. I was in Switzerland when they voted to support the convention, they stopped making and selling cluster bombs. There was a good deal of new coverage of the carnage caused by these things. I'm glad to see this article, we need to keep the spotlight on issues like this.

Can you imagine ? $2,500 to each family for the horror they endured ? When a person thinks about what humans have done to this planet, having these types of weapons still scattered about, It just boggles the mind.
Who knows what new and destructive killing machines are being devised as we read this ? Thank for this story.

What kind of minds dream up these things? Can they sleep at night? Of course they can. They were just doing their job.
Brilliant article.
Interesting piece of history that could have been lost forever. Thanks for preserving it. I hope those families got more that $2.5k in the end.

Thank you for your superb reporting.  As a recovering Army Cavalry Scout during the ground invasion of Iraq and Kuwait, I drove a canvas and plastic Humvee through thousands of miles of  battlefields littered with these horror-inducing yellow cluster bombs.  Friends were wounded.  Often, the sands would partially or completely obscure the bomb, exponentially increasing the hidden danger.  Worse, often times the only way we knew we entered a cluster bomb field was by sighting what we called "banana peels," the exterior of the larger bomb dropped from an aircraft that contained the cluster bombs.  Too often, I drove over the unexploded munitions, and I am happy every day that I survived.  The banana peels and the Iraq land mines were and remain extraordinary horrors of war.  They need to be identified and cleaned up.  Now.  ~ Paul Sullivan
Thank you John for another excellent piece.  As we discussed,  these stories need to be told.
Excellent and interesting piece on the history of a dangerous instrument of war. Keep the articles coming John, I enjoy your work. -“Initial success or total failure”
